title: Bans and the lies we get told.
body:
So for those who don't know, in league the banning system follows this punishment system ( https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/207489286-Instant-Feedback-System-FAQ- ) where bad behaviour is punished in certain tiers of punishments.

First Offense: 10 Game Chat Restriction
Second Offense: 25 Game Chat Restriction
Third Offense: Two Week Suspension
Fourth Offense: Permanent Suspension

At one point an addition was made to this, those who are new here might not be aware, but there was a list of words added to a blacklist that if you were reported for them, you would be instantly escalated to a third offense, with no chance of having it looked at as anything else.

This list included words such as KYS, but also things that (at the time) are really more tame, but hey this is a good system right?

Well turns out this is no longer the case, so let's get started on what has happened recently.

So 21 days ago, i was in a game of normals with a 4 man premade, they shit talked me constantly and one of them told me to KYS at some point throughout the game, and obviously i reported this person in particular, what should happen is that because this person said KYS it should have been an instant 14 day ban, but of course we all know it's not that easy.

A few days later, i end up talking with Seras Dragon, someone with access to Riot employees who told me he would pass on this information, and that it might take a while because they are busy with clash weekend coming up (to give even more context on the timing on when this was done.)

About a week after this, i thought this would be the end of the story, this person hadn't played for 3 days, but i decided to double check and looked again today.

Turns out that a quick look, shows that he never recieved a 14 day ban, and in fact the longest period of time this person hasn't played a game is 3 days.

I was told by Seras that apparently it is possible even hardline phrases don't instantly trigger full bans anymore, but even with riot intervention this person never recieved a ban for saying KYS to a player.

So ultimately what does this actually mean?

It means that Riot either no longer believes that saying KYS to players is enough to institute a 14 day ban, or that even these volunteers on these boards don't have nearly as much pull as they thought they do, and have something closer to tickets that we non-volunteers have access to (you know, the ones that take weeks and never result in anything)

Ultimately, this is a punch in the face, back when this system was introduced i got an instant 14 day ban with no history for saying one word to someone, and yet now days, this person likely didn't even get a chat restriction.

I did try and add him, however obviously, he didn't add me back, which is to be expect of someone you told to KYS when they try to add you.

But i do have to ask, why does this system not scan for these hardline phrases at all anymore?

Hell even my report wasn't enough to cause a scan, and even if it did, somehow these phrases are now tame enough that it's ok to say to someone?

I'd like to see Riot actively respond to this, instead of hiding behind the volunteers which i expect to respond instead of them.

And Sera's you know the person, you can check the account, not like i'm making this up.

replies.body:
There are two major misconceptions here, which I did my best to clear up when we chatted in client, but clearly it didn't take.

1. The system does not (and *cannot*) function on keywords. **[This post](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/Ifb0rpEJ-riot-should-just-make-a-list-of-banned-words-and-how-not-to-be-condescending)** does a very good job of explaining why, and the basic principle by how the system *does* work.
.
2. There is no single behaviour that *guarantees* escalation. There are behaviours that open that as an avenue for the system to use where it deems appropriate, as opposed to the less severe behaviours which will always follow the normal path. This was a misconception I have had in the past, and I have since clarified. It is also reflected in the FAQ you linked.

Some other points that may be relevant here include:

1. "No history of punishment" is not the same as "no history of negativity".
.
2. No two cases are the same. The system has an enormous wealth of background information that we as players do not (and will never) have access to about the players we report. If person A was punished differently from person B, *there is a reason for that*.
.
3. Obfuscation is frustrating, but it is also necessary. As soon as you set a hard line and say "do not cross this", people will skirt the edge while being as toxic as possible. A rule like "Don't be a Jerk" is much easier to *follow* as well as moderate. It is subjective yes, but that is the purpose of chat restrictions, to pull people up when they are skirting too close to the *M-rated, public space* definition of "Jerk".

I will not pretend to think you will ever agree, but I can do my best to clarify. Anything else will get off-topic fast, so I'm not going to say any more on this.

I believe a few years ago the Riot report system went into a much more streamline automation system. It was a big shock for me because I liked the old system and felt confident that punishments would be given out appropriately. Since my return from a 2 year hiatus of not playing I am not confident anymore. As far as issues go it's not in the top 3 of Riots biggest issues for me since I know that I have a mute button and or the ability to deescalate situations if I really wanted to but knowing that it falls back on me having to do it because I don't have confidence in the system doesn't make my experience of gaming as enjoyable as it should be.

No system is perfect, but the old system had more than it's fair share of issues.

I think this comes down to, why don't you have confidence in the system anymore?

Statistically speaking, the new system is more accurate, requires far less oversight, punishes more immediately, and is more effective at preventing repeat occurrences of negative behaviour than the old system was. *It's not perfect*, but there is a reason the new system stuck around.

I don't know the eccentricities of the system but I have noticed that reports don't even get looked at unless it's real bad or multiple people report. I have had several reports sent and at least half of them I have heard of other people got punished for the exact same issue but these ones didn't. Obviously different circumstances could have called for different measures but compared to the old system I don't see results like I used to. I have no doubt I am probably a minority and you being more on the inside of the system you get a better look at how it works and the rewards of the change but I personally can't see it. 
I really do feel like the more minor things slip threw the cracks a lot easier and I also feel like a more automated system allows for the toxic rioters to take advantage of what they can and can't get away with if they know what the system is looking for. 
Anyway no matter what there will always be bugs and disadvantages to every system used so you may as well just go with what gives the best results statistically like you said. 
If anything like you say the people who are in charge are in charge for a reason and the judgement they make is for a reason so all we can do is hope that it is a genuine one with good intent for us and the game!

Depends what you mean by "looked at". Any report will trigger a review of the game and player in question by the automated system. It's a machine learning system that works on context, not on keywords (as explained in the post I linked), since keywords are extremely easy to dodge.

Edge cases (e.g a player that gets reported every single game but the system can't determine why) or reports submitted through support tickets are subject to manual review, but it's a much slower process.

From what I've seen, the biggest thing that makes people think the system isn't working is the lack of feedback. In the interest of reform and privacy in general, Riot or Support will *never* give out information about another player's account. Aside from looking for gaps in match history, you have no way of knowing if a player has been punished, and this leads people to believe that nothing is happening even when it is.

There is one notification that *sometimes* appears, but it is extremely limited. Seeing it guarantees a punishment was issued, but not seeing it does not mean one wasn't.

Another thing to consider is population. The old system required basically universal oversight (essentially making it a manual Riot reviewed system anyway), and that just isn't scalable. Such a system would not function with the population that the game now has.

I get the feeling also, that you are confusing "Rioters" and "players". To be clear, a Rioter is an official employee of Riot Games, **not** someone who just plays the game.
